Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Epidural and Paravertebral Analgesia for Minimally Invasive Esophagectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size calculation determined that 192 patients were needed to detect a minimally clinically important difference in QoR-40 scores.

Participants.evidence: Adult patients scheduled for transthoracic MIE with intrathoracic anastomosis were randomised to receive either epidural or paravertebral analgesia.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either epidural or paravertebral analgesia.

Objective.evidence: Paravertebral analgesia may offer a promising alternative to epidural analgesia, potentially reducing side effects and enhancing postoperative recovery in patients undergoing minimally invasive esophagectomy (MIE).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Quality of Recovery (QoR-40) score on the third postoperative day (POD3).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified per center using block randomisation, and allocation was not concealed.

Blinding.evidence: This open-label, multicenter, randomised controlled superiority trial

Number_Randomised.evidence: From December 2019 to June 2022, 192 patients were randomised: 94 to epidural and 98 to paravertebral analgesia.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The intention-to-treat analysis showed no significant difference in QoR-40 scores on POD3 between groups

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with no significant differences in complications or mortality.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered in the Dutch Trial Register (NL8037).

Funding.evidence: The trial was funded by institutional sources.
